docs.lead_paragraph: More health risks may be associated with off-road vehicles than just rolling over. A new study raises the possibility that off-road activities increase the spread of the deadly hantavirus in mice that live near such popular recreation areas. Researchers from the University of Utah and the University of Nevada, writing in the journal Emerging Infectious Diseases, said they found an unusually high hantavirus rate in deer mice caught in the Little Sahara Recreation Area, a central Utah off-roader site.

headline.main: Hantavirus Found Near the Beaten Track

docs.abstract: New study finds that off-road vehicles increase spread of hantavirus (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The fog was lifting, and my wife's voice echoed thinly across the recovery room. ''The surgery was successful,'' she said. ''The operation lasted over six hours.'' I cut to the chase. ''Did they do an ileostomy?''

headline.main: Trouble With 'The Bag' Is in the Head

docs.lead_paragraph: ''100 Years of American Nursing: Celebrating a Century of Caring,'' edited by Thelma M. Schorr and Maureen Shawn Kennedy, Lippincott, $38.95. Just about everyone has heard of the English nurse and hospital reformer Florence Nightingale, the ''lady with the lamp,'' and the darling of soldiers in the Crimean War. The same can be said of Clara Barton, founder of the American Red Cross, and of Margaret Sanger, the public health nurse who founded the American birth control movement.

headline.main: A Century of Service, Battlefield to Bedside

docs.abstract: John Langone reviews book 100 Years of American Nursing: Celebrating a Century of Caring; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tinnitus is well known as a disease that affects the ears, but researchers now suspect that the eyes may also play a role. Millions of people have the disease, characterized by a ringing or buzzing in the ears and linked to a variety of quality of life problems, including depression and sleep disruption. It is most common in men and the elderly.

headline.main: A Role for Eyes in Ringing of the Ears

docs.abstract: Researchers now suspect that eyes may play role in tinnitus, disease characterized by ringing in their ears (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers from Johns Hopkins University are reporting a strong link between alcohol consumption and bicycle injuries and deaths. After studying the cases of bicyclists killed in Maryland, the researchers found that a third of the riders had had elevated blood-alcohol levels.

headline.main: Drunken Riding: An Invitation for Injury

docs.abstract: Researchers from Johns Hopkins University report finding strong link between alcohol consumption and bicycle injuries and deaths (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A substance used to thicken shampoo and lipstick is now making its way into medicine, potentially improving the effectiveness of drugs to battle diseases like hepatitis C, diabetes and cancer. By itself, the substance, known as polyethylene glycol, or PEG, does not heal, battle germs or kill cancer, although it is prescribed as a laxative before bowel surgery.

headline.main: Cloaked in Stealth Molecules, Drugs Sneak Past the Body's Defenses

docs.abstract: Substance known as polyethylene glycol, or PEG, used to thicken shampoo and lipstick, is now making its way into medicine, potentially improving effectiveness of drugs to battle diseases like hepatitis C, diabetes and cancer; body almost entirely ignores PEG's, which makes them useful for medicines; when PEG's are attached to other molecules in process known as pegylation, body also ignores attached molecules, thus providing an invisibility cloak to drugs that otherwise would be dismantled by body's immune defenses or flushed out by kidneys (M)
docs.snippet: A substance used to thicken shampoo and lipstick is now making its way into medicine, potentially improving the effectiveness of drugs to battle diseases like hepatitis C, diabetes and cancer.    By itself, the substance, known as polyethylene...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Atlanta put strict driving rules in effect for the 1996 summer Olympics, air pollution dropped. But something else went down, too: the number of children seeking treatment for acute asthma. Doctors have long believed that the ozone in automobile pollution contributes to childhood asthma, a major and worsening problem. But rare is the opportunity to put the theory to the test, because car use is increasing.

headline.main: Leaving Asthma Behind, With the Car

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that number of children in Atlanta seeking treatment for acute asthma drop after city put strict driving rules into effect for 1996 summer Olympics (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. How do birds breathe? Is it more like mammals or like fish? A. Like mammals, birds take in air and extract oxygen from it to supply body tissues, while fish respiration depends on getting the oxygen dissolved in water through organs called gills.
docs.abstract: Answer to reader's query about how birds breath

docs.lead_paragraph: Alice Riddle, an 80-year-old retired Brooklynite, used to drive everywhere. But in her mid-70's, she realized that her reflexes were not as good as they once were, and she no longer felt comfortable behind the wheel of a car. So she stopped driving, gave her car to a grandson and started relying on family members and sometimes on friends to provide transportation.

headline.main: For Older Drivers, a Wealth of Alternatives

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column, second of two on older drivers, says that older drivers must honestly assess their driving ability, make accommodations for their limitations and perhaps change when and where they choose to drive; discusses alternative transportation options for those who must give up driving (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Think your child is a natural-born musician? You may well be right. But, a new study suggests, everyone is.

headline.main: Your Baby May Be Wailing Right on Key

docs.abstract: Study finds that newborns may possess perfect pitch, trait rare among adults, even musicians (S)
